Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language varies as levels of formality and social distance increase
Elaboration: Recognising language protocols for formal address; for example, words used to address principals heads of state and monarchs
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrating levels of formality, social distance and culturally appropriate behaviours through teacher-supported discussion and role play

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language varies as levels of formality and social distance increase
Elaboration: Discussing levels of language such as slang, colloquial, conversational and formal, and how their appropriateness changes with the situation and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that language varies as levels of formality and social distance increase
Elaboration: Presenting ideas and opinions at levels of formality appropriate to the context and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language and identify bias
Elaboration: Identifying language choices that evoke emotion and judgements in direct and indirect ways, and how they are used to persuade different audiences to take a position and/or action
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •multiple opportunities to compare objective and subjective language, e.g. ‘That person has 5 coats’ (objective) and ‘That person has too many coats’ (subjective)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language and identify bias
Elaboration: Understanding when to share feelings and opinions; for example, in a personal recount, and when to remain more objective; for example, in a factual recount

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language and identify bias
Elaboration: Differentiating between reporting the facts; for example, in a factual recount or unedited photograph, and providing a commentary; for example, in an editorial

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts across the curriculum are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Exploring a range of everyday, community, literary and informative texts, discussing elements of text structure and language features, and comparing the overall structure and effect of authors' choices in 2 or more texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher deconstruction and joint reconstruction of texts into characteristic stages and phases

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts across the curriculum are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Examining a text to identify strategies such as exaggeration to create humour

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts across the curriculum are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Recognising that texts are organised into stages such as an introduction and that introductions may be divided into phases; for example, the introduction stage of a narrative may begin with a phase that is a "hook" or a flashback

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts across the curriculum are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Explaining the characteristic stages and phases in reviews, discussions of alternative positions or historical recounts and identifying any adaptations of typical structures or language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that cohesion can be created by the intentional use of repetition and the use of word associations
Elaboration: Noting how a general word is often used for a more specific word already mentioned (word association); for example, "look at those apples. granny smiths are my favourite."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using graphic organisers to record the repetition of key words in a poem or short story and discussing with a peer the effect of this repetition

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that cohesion can be created by the intentional use of repetition and the use of word associations
Elaboration: Recognising how cohesion can be developed through repeating key words or by using synonyms or antonyms

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how embedded clauses can expand the variety of complex sentences to elaborate extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Investigating how the choice of conjunctions enables the construction of complex sentences to extend to elaborate on and to explain ideas; for example, "the town that was flooded suffered extensive damage."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how embedded clauses can expand the variety of complex sentences to elaborate extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Creating complex sentences with embedded clauses to expand noun groups; for example, "hamish studied the rock samples that he had collected on the excursion, to complete his report."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how ideas can be expanded and sharpened through careful choice of verbs elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups
Elaboration: Knowing that the simple present tense is typically used to talk about present states; for example "he lives in darwin." or actions that happen regularly in the present; for example, "he watches television every night." or that represent "timeless" happenings, in information reports; for example, "bears hibernate in winter."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •building vocabulary in context (for example, practical demonstration of multiple verbs (slice; snip, saw) that can be substituted for ‘cut’ for greater precision relative to the context

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how ideas can be expanded and sharpened through careful choice of verbs elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups
Elaboration: Knowing that there are various ways in english to refer to future time: using the auxiliary "will"; for example, "she will call you tomorrow.”, using the present tense; for example, "tomorrow i leave for hobart.”, and using adverbials of time; for example, "she arrives in the morning."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how ideas can be expanded and sharpened through careful choice of verbs elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups
Elaboration: Using precise verbs; for example “slice", “dice", "fillet" and "segment" rather than general words; for example, "cut"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and explain how images figures tables diagrams maps and graphs contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Observing how sequential events can be represented visually by a series of images, including comic strips, timelines, photo stories, procedure diagrams and flowcharts, life-cycle diagrams and the flow of images in picture books
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of the added meaning given to a text by including visual material and opportunities to explore several examples

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and explain how images figures tables diagrams maps and graphs contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Observing how concepts, information and relationships can be represented visually through tables, maps, graphs and diagrams

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and explain how images figures tables diagrams maps and graphs contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Understanding that images and maps may be sensitive for first nations australians and ensuring that a disclaimer is applied or judgement is used about cultural appropriateness and sensitivities

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify authors' use of vivid emotive vocabulary such as metaphors similes personification idioms imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Exploring how figurative language; for example, metaphors, personification and idioms, can be used to create vivid and less predictable shades of meaning
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •multiple opportunities to listen to emotive vocabulary and devices used in spoken texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify authors' use of vivid emotive vocabulary such as metaphors similes personification idioms imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Identifying authors' use of vivid and emotive vocabulary in persuasive texts; for example, the vocabulary used in reviews

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify authors' use of vivid emotive vocabulary such as metaphors similes personification idioms imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Discussing texts using vocabulary to name text structure, literary devices and language features; for example, using words that name the literary device used in a poem

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how to use the comma for lists to separate a dependent clause from an independent clause and in dialogue
Elaboration: Identifying different uses of commas such as commas and conjunctions between independent clauses in compound sentences

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how to use the comma for lists to separate a dependent clause from an independent clause and in dialogue
Elaboration: Using commas in dialogue; for example, ben said, “i want pie, peas, carrots and chips for dinner, followed by ice cream for dessert, please.”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical social or cultural contexts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing the influence historical, social and cultural experiences may have on the meaning of a text and attitudes towards characters, actions and events
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of literary texts that reflect their cultural heritage, and opportunities to share responses to characters and events in these texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical social or cultural contexts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Sharing responses about how heroes are portrayed in science fiction or fantasy and more realistic settings

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical social or cultural contexts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring reviews of australian films

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Identify similarities and differences in literary texts on similar topics themes or plots
Elaboration: Exploring texts on a similar topic by authors with very different styles; for example, comparing fantasy quest novels or realistic novels on a specific theme
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating a bank of expressions that can be used to describe similarities and differences, e.g. ‘similar to’, ‘the same as’, ‘like text A, text B...’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Identify similarities and differences in literary texts on similar topics themes or plots
Elaboration: Identifying differences in the use of narrator, narrative structure and voice, and language and visual features, between texts and determining how these influence readers or viewers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain characteristics that define an author's individual style
Elaboration: Exploring 2 or more texts by the same author, identifying similarities; for example, subject or theme, characterisation, text structure, plot development, tone, vocabulary, voice, favoured grammatical structures and visual techniques in picture books, and determining the qualities that characterise an author's style

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain characteristics that define an author's individual style
Elaboration: Focusing on a first nations australian author and identifying characteristic elements of their writing; for example, images, theme and language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and explain characteristics that define an author's individual style
Elaboration: Comparing similarities and differences between texts, including those by the same author or illustrator, and identifying the characteristics that define an author's style; for example, comparing illustrations in picture books by the same illustrator, noting characteristic features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in poetry
Elaboration: Explaining how imagery builds emotional connections and engagement with the story or theme
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to listen to analyse and discuss the way authors use devices such as assonance, alliteration and onomatopoeia in poetry

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in poetry
Elaboration: Identifying the imagery used in narratives or poetry about first nations australians' country/place

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in poetry
Elaboration: Describing the effects of assonance, alliteration and onomatopoeia in a poem

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in poetry
Elaboration: Explaining the effect of rhythm in ballads

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that adapt plot structure characters settings and/or ideas from texts students have experienced and experiment with literary devices
Elaboration: Creating narratives in written spoken or multimodal/digital form adapting character; for example, reimagining the hero in an adventure story
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •scaffolded activities to focus on how a setting, character or idea can be adapted to create various effects, e.g. experiment with the effects created if a setting is changed from a historical period to contemporary times

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that adapt plot structure characters settings and/or ideas from texts students have experienced and experiment with literary devices
Elaboration: Creating an autobiography of a character from a text explored

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that adapt plot structure characters settings and/or ideas from texts students have experienced and experiment with literary devices
Elaboration: Discussing the setting in a literary text with a peer during the editing process, and experimenting with literary devices that may enhance the setting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts including media texts that represent ideas and events and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Identifying news reports of the same type of event over time and how they reflect their contexts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of the context behind a media text which may include details about key personalities, events, attitudes and cultural influences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts including media texts that represent ideas and events and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Comparing advertising posters for animated children's films in different countries and explaining the impact of these choices on audience expectations of the film

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts including media texts that represent ideas and events and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Identifying how advertisements for the same products reflect the context in which they were created

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing questioning clarifying and interrogating ideas developing and supporting arguments and sharing and evaluating information experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Participating in pair, group, class, school and community speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, discussions, debates and presentations
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating a bank of vocabulary to question and clarify ideas, eg. ‘What do you mean by...?’, ‘Could you give an example of...?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing questioning clarifying and interrogating ideas developing and supporting arguments and sharing and evaluating information experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Participating in pair, group, class, school and community speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, discussions, debates and presentations
EALDElaboration: •practising paraphrasing by finding synonyms for key words in an argument

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing questioning clarifying and interrogating ideas developing and supporting arguments and sharing and evaluating information experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Using strategies; for example, pausing, questioning, rephrasing, repeating, summarising, reviewing and asking clarifying questions when discussing topics

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing questioning clarifying and interrogating ideas developing and supporting arguments and sharing and evaluating information experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Recognising that closed questions ask for precise responses while open questions prompt a speaker to provide more information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how text structures and language features work together to meet the purpose of a text and engage and influence audiences
Elaboration: Comparing the structure and language features of different texts, including print and digital sources on similar topics, and evaluating which features best aid navigation and clear communication about the topic
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •deconstructing texts to identify language used to engage and influence the audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select navigate and read texts for a range of purposes monitoring meaning and evaluating the use of structural features; for example table of contents glossary chapters headings and subheadings
Elaboration: Bringing subject and technical vocabulary and concept knowledge to new reading tasks, selecting, evaluating and using texts for their pertinence to the task and the accuracy of their information
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •scaffolded activities to practice navigating tables of content and finding specific chapters in a book or online resource

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select navigate and read texts for a range of purposes monitoring meaning and evaluating the use of structural features; for example table of contents glossary chapters headings and subheadings
Elaboration: Bringing subject and technical vocabulary and concept knowledge to new reading tasks, selecting, evaluating and using texts for their pertinence to the task and the accuracy of their information
EALDElaboration: •teacher-supported discussions about ways headings and sub-headings flag content and information in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select navigate and read texts for a range of purposes monitoring meaning and evaluating the use of structural features; for example table of contents glossary chapters headings and subheadings
Elaboration: Using knowledge of text structure to navigate the text to locate specific literal content for a purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select navigate and read texts for a range of purposes monitoring meaning and evaluating the use of structural features; for example table of contents glossary chapters headings and subheadings
Elaboration: Using research skills including locating texts, gathering and organising information, evaluating and using information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Making connections between the text and students' own experience or other texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of inferences in a text, e.g. ‘‘The people clutched cold drinks and crowded around the fan.’ The inference is that it is a hot day

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Making connections between information in print and images

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Using prior knowledge and textual information to make inferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Asking and answering questions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Using graphic organisers to visualise connections categories and hierarchies of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning and to connect and compare content from a variety of sources
Elaboration: Summarising a text or part of a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Creating informative texts for 2 different audiences that explore a topic using text structure and language features for the identified audiences, noting the changes required to appeal to each audience
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •oral activities to build topic knowledge and practise language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Creating informative texts for 2 different audiences that explore a topic using text structure and language features for the identified audiences, noting the changes required to appeal to each audience
EALDElaboration: •teacher–supported joint construction of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Creating informative texts for 2 different audiences that explore a topic using text structure and language features for the identified audiences, noting the changes required to appeal to each audience
EALDElaboration: •guided editing of texts to explore synonyms for key words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Using rhetorical devices, images and modal verbs for persuasive effects, for an identified audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Selecting and combining digital tools to create texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal texts whose purposes may be imaginative informative and persuasive using paragraphs a variety of complex sentences expanded verb groups tense topic-specific and vivid vocabulary punctuation spelling and visual features
Elaboration: Re-reading and editing their own and others' work using negotiated criteria for text structure, meaning and accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and explaining editing choices as required

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include information arguments and details that develop a theme or idea organising ideas using precise topic-specific and technical vocabulary pitch tone pace volume and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Planning a report on a topic, sequencing ideas logically and providing supporting detail including graphics, sound, and visuals to enhance audience engagement and understanding
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •the opportunity to present in smaller groups to build their confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include information arguments and details that develop a theme or idea organising ideas using precise topic-specific and technical vocabulary pitch tone pace volume and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Planning a report on a topic, sequencing ideas logically and providing supporting detail including graphics, sound, and visuals to enhance audience engagement and understanding
EALDElaboration: •oral activities to build topic knowledge and practise language features before composing spoken texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include information arguments and details that develop a theme or idea organising ideas using precise topic-specific and technical vocabulary pitch tone pace volume and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Experimenting with voice effects such as tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal presentations and recognising the effects these have on audience understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include information arguments and details that develop a theme or idea organising ideas using precise topic-specific and technical vocabulary pitch tone pace volume and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Presenting an argument about an issue from learning area content, which includes claims supported with evidence and examples, careful use of topic-specific vocabulary and selection of persuasive techniques appropriate to audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations that include information arguments and details that develop a theme or idea organising ideas using precise topic-specific and technical vocabulary pitch tone pace volume and visual and digital features
Elaboration: Setting goals for a presentation and monitoring development in a written or digital journal

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phonic knowledge of common and less common grapheme-phoneme relationships to read and write increasingly complex words
Elaboration: Using phonic generalisations to read and write complex words with uncommon letter patterns; for example, “pneumonia”, “resuscitate” and “vegetation”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Using a dictionary to explore and using knowledge of word origins including some greek roots to spell words; for example, the greek root "ath" meaning "contest" or "outstanding skill”, "pent" meaning the number 5 and "dec" meaning the number 10 inform the spelling and meaning of the words “athlete", "pentathlon" and "decathlon"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Applying accumulated knowledge of a wide range of letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words; for example, "ratio" and "synthesis"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Expanding knowledge of prefixes and suffixes, and exploring meaning relationships between words; for example, “disappearance”, “submarine”, “subterranean”, “poisonous” and “nervous”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Applying accumulated knowledge of a wide range of letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words; for example, knowing how and why these words are spelt as follows: “reliability", “handkerchief", “receive", “lollies", “trolleys", “climbing", "designed" and "emergency"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Spelling technical words by applying morphemic knowledge; for example, “metaphorical", "biology" and "biodegradable"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of known words word origins including some latin and greek roots base words prefixes suffixes letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words including technical words
Elaboration: Investigating the meanings of words in languages of first nations australians using dictionaries or online resources from state libraries or universities
